attachments.title: New tools for reducing compiler latency
attachments.text: I’m pleased to announce the release of SnoopCompile 2.2.0, a major enhancement in the suite of tools for reducing “time to first plot.” This release provides considerably better insight into the costs of type inference, allowing you to profile the actions of inference in extensive detail. It also provides a new suite of tools for detecting and analyzing “inference triggers,” cases where a previously-uninferred method is called via runtime dispatch. As a quick visual for the new release, I’ll pa...

text: Basically, it's a *lot* to chew. So I thought maybe a series of shorter posts would help. Of course people can just go straight to the docs, but sometimes a more expansive explanation helps a larger audience.

elements.text: to chew. So I thought maybe a series of shorter posts would help. Of course people can just go straight to the docs, but sometimes a more expansive explanation helps a larger audience.

text: It's just that this flame graph is super useful for an end user that has code that is itself not super expensive but depends on a lot of packages and they want to figure out which ones are slowing down latency

elements.text: It's just that this flame graph is super useful for an end user that has code that is itself not super expensive but depends on a lot of packages and they want to figure out which ones are slowing down latency

text: So it makes sense for a non expert user to look at even if they don't want to invest the time to look at the finer points of latency reduction
